trial_identification.studytitle: Muscle adaptation to 14 days of immobilization after ankle aprain
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of ankle joint immobilization for second degree ankle sprain on electrical and functional properties of dorsi and plantarflexor muscles

conditions.healthcondition: Identify the electrical and functional adaptations of dorsiflexor and plantarflexor muscles after two weeks of immobilization in subjects who suffered ankle sprain

interventions.interventions: 11 subjects who suffered a second degree of ankle sprain underwent 14 days of ankle joint immobilization with a plaster cast. After removal of the plaster cast, were obtained bilaterally evaluations of: (1) leg circumference; (2) ankle joint range of motion (ROM); (3) maximal isometric torque of plantar and dorsiflexors obtained in seven different angles; and (4) electromyographic signals of the tibialis anterior, gastrocnemius medialis and soleus muscles.
interventions.comparator: The injuried leg was compared with the contralateral health leg of the subjects.

primaryOutcome.outcome: After removal of the plaster cast, were obtained bilaterally evaluation of the maximal isometric torque of plantar and dorsiflexors obtained in seven different angles in an isokinetic dynamometer.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 24 hours after removal of the plaster cast.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: After removal of the plaster cast, were obtained bilaterally evaluation of the electromyographic signals of the tibialis anterior, gastrocnemius medialis and soleus muscles.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within 24 hours after removal of the plaster cast.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Subjects who suffered a second degree of ankle sprain underwent 14 days of ankle joint immobilization with a plaster cast.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: We excluded from the study: subjects who suffered degree I or III ankle sprains; subjects who suffered another associate injuries (like fractures); subjects with previous history of injuries in lower limbs that may impair performance on isokinetic tests.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Exercise Research Laboratory School of Physical Education Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul Rua Felizardo, 750 Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil ZIP CODE 90690-200

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This research was performed to identify the adaptations of dorsiflexor and plantarflexor muscles after two weeks of immobilization in subjects who suffered ankle sprain. Eleven subjects (six women and five men) who suffered a second degree of ankle sprain underwent 14 days of ankle joint immobilization with a plaster cast. After removal of the plaster cast, were obtained bilaterally evaluations of: (1) leg circumference; (2) ankle joint range of motion (ROM); (3) maximal isometric torque of plantar and dorsiflexors obtained in seven different angles; and (4) electromyographic signals of the tibialis anterior, gastrocnemius medialis and soleus muscles. Results obtained in the immobilized side were compared to the contralateral healthy side.
